author: CCChristopherson
body: I own ZBRA which was up 8% after earnings beat yesterday. I like the stock so I didn’t want to sell but I thought it would come back to earth today (currently down 4%).  I doubt I’ll do this but curious if others have - Does anyone ever do covered calls or puts on an earnings pump on a stock they own? Seems like the majority of time stocks lose some of their post-earnings gains

author: EngineeriusMaximus
body: I was thinking that synthetic positions are cheap leverage. For example, a 2023 SPY synthetic (one short ATM put, one long ATM call) currently requires \~$14,700 in collateral and 0 cash, and a SPY ZEBRA requires $12000 in cash. Both of these represent $46,000 worth of SPY, so you are getting 3x+ leverage. You can get even lower collateral requirements if you go a little OTM on both the put and call, e.g. short 430 put and long 485 call, with collateral of just over $10k. These make sense to hold for long periods as leveraged SPY plays, right?

author: analnapalm
body: I don't have anything significant on my short term radar and am mostly cash as I feel the market is a little overheated at the moment.  Long term, it's difficult to imagine not seeing QQQ, NVDA, & AAPL somewhere in my portfolio.  Perhaps also TGT and ZBRA.

author: devopsdudeinthebay
body: You can do a ZEBRA. Sell one of the $55 calls, then buy two of the $40 calls. Will cost about $2800 to open. You could then also sell shorter term OTM calls against it, like a PMCC. The advantage of a ZEBRA over a regular PMCC is that the position doesn't lose much value if the underlying stays sideways. And IIRC a ZEBRA should be less sensitive to IV crush. But you have less leverage than a PMCC, too.

author: Ronikan
body:
OP just learned what options were last week. I pray to God he doesn’t yolo into a ZEBRA. That said that’s clever about selling calls against it like a PMCC. 

Personally the best part about ZEBRAs is the high delta combined with lack of extrinsic. PMCC is fun until the underlying blows up and you have to exit early.

author: ankole_watusi
body:
The idea that one company will own AR/VR is of course ridiculous.

While it’s cool you can converse in a virtual space with some uncanny creepy experience that simulates being in the same space, that will largely continue to be a novelty outside of games.

There are lots of practical applications in business - especially in warehousing, manufacturing, distribution. And FB is not going to be anyone’s go to.

One company to watch closely is Zebra.

author: mjr2015
body: Thanks for the heads up this is definitely a good time to buy back my 2024 zebra

author: cowsbeek
body:
Scope out the holdings under the $BOTZ etf. All about automation robotics and IoT. Other thoughts - Honeywell, Zebra, IBM, Dexcom, Impinj. Extremely short list for a growing sector. 

Also - if you’re into crypto - you must check our Helium.

author: slutpriest
body:
I usually have 0 to do with anything that involves buying/selling shares.

"ZEBRAs are about as capital efficient as a single LEAPs for selling CCs on under the following comparisons: same expiration; LEAP at 0.85 delta.

Pros:

A properly set up ZEBRA will not cost any extrinsic

Cons:

More complex management

Less room to sell CCs if the stock takes a short term decline (higher strike on the ZEBRA LEAPS compared to the PMCC)

The short ATM call for the ZEBRA can be ASSIGNED at any time you are profitable. This seems like a big issue to me at first glance, but it would be unlikely for it to occur as the purchaser of the call would be giving up considerable extrinsic to do so. The owner of the ZEBRA wins in this case as they would pocket the net difference in extrinsic and be left with a 0.7+ delta leap to continue the PMCC.

ZEBRA: [https://optionstrat.com/STlUK5KPozt8](https://optionstrat.com/STlUK5KPozt8)

LEAPS: [https://optionstrat.com/gZXCvwAR2laT](https://optionstrat.com/gZXCvwAR2laT)

In my mind the ZEBRA is theoretically better for higher IV stocks that you expect volatility expansion or stability. That's because you can manipulate the deltas of the short LEAPS and your short call to sell weekly or monthly ATM covered calls and hopefully make more premium."

author: GimmeAllDaTendiesNow
body:
Purchasing shares to cover a short position can work, but it can also work against you. It's a very capital-intensive way to cover the position in any case. I've done it before both successful and not. A more capital-efficient way of doing this is cover the short with a deep ITM long option or a ZEBRA. I prefer ZEBRAs, especially long-dated.

You are always going to get a lot of sanctimonious knee-jerk responses about selling calls from people who have no idea what they are talking about. As someone who has sold naked calls for years, it's risky and it's a lot harder to make money than by put-selling. There's also a lot of value to balanced delta in my opinion. 

Most of the time lately they are either challenged or at an unrealized loss, but rarely ITM, depending on your entry delta. You usually get a month or two out of the year where they are the only thing that pays. It's easy to not be stupid about it. Don't trade meme stocks and don't sell 400 naked puts on a $20K account. The last few months have been rough, because a lot of stuff is up significantly more than volatility had priced in. Vol is just way under priced right now. I have strangles on MSFT, CVS, WMT and XRT that have all blown way past my short call strike. I'm inverted on all of them. At the same time, a lot of stuff has tanked and gone way past my short put strikes.

author: releb
body: I usually sell options but there are some good long theta plays. However these usually require more capital than a plain long call. The best one IMO is the stock replacement leap. Basically buy a near 100 delta deep itm call. Best to use when IV is low. Another one is a short atm put to buy a long atm call and the zebra which is long two itm calls versus 1 short atm call. Each strategy aims for a 100 delta with as little theta as possible.

author: questionr
body: Zebra looks like it hurts more on the downside than a synthetic stock combo, but Zebra gives you better returns to the upside. A synthetic would only expire worthless if the underlying dropped to $0. A Zebra expires worthless if the underlying drops just under the strike of the calls.

author: lithium_leo
body:
There’s a lot of opinions here on your OP, and it really boils down to various factors everyone is considering from their own perspectives.  

Those suggesting simply owning shares and selling covered calls are taking a more conservative approach in case the SPY crashes.  They can technically “hold forever” and one day realize profitability while collecting some pocket change along the way.  But if it did tank, how long will that capital be tied up?  And it’s quite a bit more capital than the contract.

The contract is somewhat more risky, in the event of a steep decline due to the time constraint and leverage, but you also utilize less capital up-front to “control” the same amount of shares - leaving you the opportunity to potentially put money in other places to offset any losses you may or may not see here. (Diversification).  Of course, you can also sell calls in this strategy as well to collect some change along the way also.  

Have you ever considered a ZEBRA LEAP?  It may not be what you’re looking for or comfortable with, but it is one more strategy that may be something worth looking into….

The other thing I think a lot of people commenting here are concerned with is an imminent “crash”.  The FED’s announced strategy of tapering each month and potentially raising rates next summer aren’t set in stone.  There’s no way JPOW and this administration will continue down that path if the market is looking like it’s going into meltdown.  They will crank that printing press back up so quick it’ll make your head spin.

author: RobertLahblaw
body:
Ahh, the good old Zebra.  70/50 delta is probably close enough for this to work, but isn't necessarily the best way to make a true zebra (zero extrinsic back ratio).  The best way is to add a column that shows the extrinsic value in the contracts and make sure that the two your buying add up to the same ev you're selling.  Works on both sides (calls and puts). 

If you're doing this on the call side, you can add and atm put to make money if the stock goes either way, just gotta make sure it goes away from your atm straddle or you'll lose money.

author: Butterscotch-Apart
body: Yea I’m not saying the picks are always trash. My brother has stock advisors account and I use it sometimes. I bought CRWD, SHOP, TTD, SQ, ODFL, CRTO, ZBRA and a few others based on their picks and doubled up or more on most of them “over 3-5 years lol”. Don’t take their picks as gospel is all I’m saying bc they’re wrong quite a bit too (PINS, SAM, SKLZ and ZNGA come to mind for recent fuck ups). Sure in 5 years all these stocks will be up but the time value of money will still likely make them poor investments in hindsight.

I doubt I’ll do this but curious if others have - Does anyone ever do covered calls or puts on an earnings pump on a stock they own? Seems like the majority of time stocks lose some of their post-earnings gains

author: EngineeriusMaximus
body: I was thinking that synthetic positions are cheap leverage. For example, a 2023 SPY synthetic (one short ATM put, one long ATM call) currently requires \~$14,700 in collateral and 0 cash, and a SPY ZEBRA requires $12000 in cash. Both of these represent $46,000 worth of SPY, so you are getting 3x+ leverage. You can get even lower collateral requirements if you go a little OTM on both the put and call, e.g. short 430 put and long 485 call, with collateral of just over $10k. These make sense to hold for long periods as leveraged SPY plays, right?

author: analnapalm
body: I don't have anything significant on my short term radar and am mostly cash as I feel the market is a little overheated at the moment.  Long term, it's difficult to imagine not seeing QQQ, NVDA, & AAPL somewhere in my portfolio.  Perhaps also TGT and ZBRA.

author: GimmeAllDaTendiesNow
body:
Purchasing shares to cover a short position can work, but it can also work against you. It's a very capital-intensive way to cover the position in any case. I've done it before both successful and not. A more capital-efficient way of doing this is cover the short with a deep ITM long option or a ZEBRA. I prefer ZEBRAs, especially long-dated.

You are always going to get a lot of sanctimonious knee-jerk responses about selling calls from people who have no idea what they are talking about. As someone who has sold naked calls for years, it's risky and it's a lot harder to make money than by put-selling. There's also a lot of value to balanced delta in my opinion. 

Most of the time lately they are either challenged or at an unrealized loss, but rarely ITM, depending on your entry delta. You usually get a month or two out of the year where they are the only thing that pays. It's easy to not be stupid about it. Don't trade meme stocks and don't sell 400 naked puts on a $20K account. The last few months have been rough, because a lot of stuff is up significantly more than volatility had priced in. Vol is just way under priced right now. I have strangles on MSFT, CVS, WMT and XRT that have all blown way past my short call strike. I'm inverted on all of them. At the same time, a lot of stuff has tanked and gone way past my short put strikes.
